docs.lead_paragraph: Aside from her spiky frosted hair, it was hard to pick out Amy Brewer in the two dozen or so black-clad dancers at the Broadway Dance Center strutting, twirling and kicking, doing the same routine 8, 10, 12, 14 times to the 30-second finale of Natalie Cole's ''Orange-Colored Sky.'' Still, Allison Ellner-Teitelbaum, who owns the five-floor studio that is ground zero for New York dance, saw something she liked amid the symphony of black spandex and high-heeled Capezio character shoes.

headline.main: As Dancing Booms on Broadway; In a Changed World, More Jobs, More Competition, Same Old Drive

docs.abstract: Dance is thriving again on Broadway after years of musicals that placed the emphasis on song and drama; there is more work for dancers in musicals like Chicago, Fosse, Footloose, Ragtime, Annie Get Your Gun and Cabaret, but there are also a lot more good dancers competing for that work; dancers have it better now than than they did in past in many ways, but they are still at the low end of Broadway's pecking order in pay and status; photos (L)

keywords.value: FOSSE: A CELEBRATION OF SONG AND DANCE (REVUE)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A spokeswoman for the Alan Guttmacher Institute, which analyzed teen-age pregnancy rates, attributes about 20 percent of the decline to decreased sexual activity and the other 80 percent to better use of contraceptives (news article, April 29).

headline.main: Behind the Drop In Teen-Age Births

docs.abstract: Letter from Helen Alvare, director of planning and information, National Conference of Catholic Bishops, questions Alan Guttmacher Institute's analysis of decline in teen-age pregnancy rate, especially institute's estimate that 80 percent of decrease is attributable to better use of contraceptives; expresses belief that growing number of teens are abstaining

docs.lead_paragraph: There were a lot of storm troopers wandering around without their blaster guns at the ''Star Wars'' Celebration here, the first convention and exposition dedicated to the 22-year-old movie series to win the approval and support of the films' creator, George Lucas. Through a strange twist of fate, the ''Star Wars'' Celebration landed in Denver on the same weekend as the National Rifle Association convention, which drew 7,000 protesters, and just 10 days after the Columbine High School shootings in Littleton, a suburb 20 minutes away. It was food for thought, not least because the ''Star Wars'' movies -- whose ''dark side'' leans heavily on the iconography of the Third Reich, an obsession of the Columbine killers -- are filled with the kind of shoot-em-up entertainment fantasy that many citizens are again blaming for society's ills.

headline.main: With the Force but No Guns; Issue Haunts 'Star Wars' Gala in Denver

docs.abstract: Star Wars Celebration in Denver, the first such gathering to have approval and support of films' creator, George Lucas, draws about 40,000 fans to Wings Over Rockies Air and Space Museum; spectre of massacre at Columbine High School in suburban Littleton hangs over celebration like Death Star; photos (M)
